test.question:
From the details of the passage, it can be learned or inferred that 

I. Dorothea and Celia are sisters. 
II. Dorothea and Celia may be orphans. 
III. Dorothea and Celia are temperamentally very alike.
The first paragraph of the passage refers to the 'infant school' and 'plan for some buildings' in order to suggest that Dorothea is
In lines 22-23, Dorothea asks Celia whether it is 'six calendar or six lunar months' because she
answers: wants to know exactly how many days have passed.
had hoped to keep the jewels from Celia.
wants to demonstrate the scientific precision of her mind.
has forgotten what the current month is.

test.question: In line 36, the phrase 'wanting in respect' can be best understood to mean
The 'argument' to which Celia has 'really applied herself' (line 46) is intended to convince Dorothea to
answers: show greater respect for their dead mother.
give all the jewels to her.
give the most valuable of the jewels to her.
agree to sharing and wearing the jewels.
examine the jewels and lock them up again.
test.answer: agree to sharing and wearing the jewels.

test.question: Although in lines 30-31 Dorothea has said, 'we should never wear them, you know', she changes her opinion because she
answers: is moved by Celia's appeal to the memory of their mother.
is convinced by Celia's reference to Madame Poincon.
realizes that Celia wants to wear the jewels.
sees how becoming the jewels are to Celia.
can appear superior to Celia by refusing to wear them herself.
test.answer: realizes that Celia wants to wear the jewels.

test.question: In lines 97-98, 'Puritanic toleration' is a reference to
answers: Celia's love of jewels and finery.

test.question: In the last sentence of the passage, the word 'unenthusiastic' refers to
answers: Dorothea's giving her permission for Celia to wear jewels.

test.question: The inconsistency in Dorothea's reasoning that the passage reveals is her
answers: forgetting about when the jewels were given to her.
losing the keys to the cabinet holding the jewels.
insistence that Christians cannot wear jewels.
wanting Celia to wear jewels but refusing to wear them herself.
deceitful claim that she honors the memory of her mother.
test.answer: wanting Celia to wear jewels but refusing to wear them herself.

test.question: The purpose of the passage as a whole is to
answers: reveal the likeness of Celia and Dorothea.
expose the submerged ill feelings between Celia and Dorothea.
reveal the differences in the natures of Celia and Dorothea.
satirize the hypocrisy of the two young women.
test.answer: reveal the differences in the natures of Celia and Dorothea.
